                <li><strong>Oscar:</strong> My red team ally. He assisted in getting us on Linux machines and dropping our beacons. He also set up a way to install Wazuh to more machines.</li>
                <li><strong>b4k3ry:</strong> Another red team ally. Grabbing shells on enemy boxes through different services and automating our beacons.</li>
            </ul>

            <div class="section-title">What Actually Happened</div>
            
            <p>Day 1 was pure chaos. We had to defend our infrastructure while also trying to understand what the hell was going on. The red team was everywhere, and we were playing catch-up most of the time.</p>

            <p>Our strategy was simple: defend what we have, understand the network, and then go on the offensive. But man, when you're in the middle of it, everything feels like it's on fire.</p>

            <div class="section-title">What You and I Actually Worked On</div>
            
            <p><strong>During the game, I worked on:</strong></p>
            <ul>
                <li><strong>Mail server recovery</strong> - Fixing Postfix on mail0, port 25 issues, SASL authentication</li>
                <li><strong>DNS infrastructure</strong> - BIND9 setup on ns0, zone management, anomaly detection</li>
                <li><strong>User account management</strong> - Cleaning up red team accounts, creating admin_clean/backup_admin, deploying universal SSH keys</li>
                <li><strong>Threat hunting</strong> - Process analysis, network monitoring, IOC collection</li>
                <li><strong>Forensics analysis</strong> - UAC tool collection, analyzing icanhasaccess activity, reviewing auth logs</li>
                <li><strong>Attack automation</strong> - Day 2 scripts, network scanning, credential testing</li>
                <li><strong>pfSense firewall management</strong> - Password resets, configuration recovery</li>
            </ul>

            <div class="section-title">Offensive Operations</div>
            
            <p>I ended up using <code>persistence.sh</code>, <code>troll.sh</code>, tried deploying malware, had my webpage running for the troll/annoyingsite/badjava stuff, and even tried messing with the blue team joes with notes on their screens that I would be back.</p>

            <p>Here's some of the offensive tools we deployed:</p>

            <div class="code-block">

                <li>Set up comprehensive logging and monitoring</li>
                <li>Implement threat hunting capabilities</li>
                <li>Establish persistence mechanisms</li>
                <li>Conduct offensive operations against enemy teams</li>
            </ul>

            <div class="section-title">Lessons Learned</div>
            
            <p>1. <strong>Communication is key</strong> - When everyone's running around like headless chickens, clear communication becomes even more critical.</p>

            <p>3. <strong>Know your team's strengths</strong> - Let people do what they're good at. Coldren on incident response, outofmemory on DNS, etc.</p>

            <p>3. <strong>Know your team's strengths</strong> - Let people do what they're good at. Coldren on incident response, outofmemory on DNS, etc.</p>
            <p>4. <strong>Document everything</strong> - When you're in the middle of chaos, good documentation saves lives.</p>

            <div class="section-title">The Aftermath</div>
            
            <p>CTF Factory, Dichotomy, and the Gold team did fantastic jobs with this event. I feel that they are running a great show and providing people wonderful opportunities.</p>

            <p>Overall, I feel like I mostly helped every individual keep to what they were doing the majority of the game. I facilitated a few points grabs from the grey team who asks for specific things like IT stuff - "can you set up these users for access", "can you install an EDR and give us some detection policies", and so on. I worked on trying to grab some artifacts for analysis, unpacked some information on the network traffic captures, and dropped a few beacons.</p>

            <p>Personally I had a goal prior to the game and worked hard on it through our workspace here, but I didn't really get to use much. And I hope to change that next year... being added on as staff last minute and co-leading the team I felt like not only did I get distracted from the plan but pulled away from it...</p>
        </div>

            <p>So... we just wrapped up Pros vs Joes CTF 2025, and holy shit, what a ride. Team B4FFL3G4P came together and made some magic happen.
